topic.title: The kitchen
topic.shortdesc: For its simplicity, pickleball has quite a few rules regarding when you can volley.

body.p: The kitchen is sometimes called the non-volley zone. It is the space within 7 feet on both sides of the net. You cannot volley while standing in the kitchen for any reason; this is a surprisingly common fault.
USAPA keeps an exhaustive list of what constitutes a kitchen fault, but it can be boiled down to five basic principles.

ol.li: If, when volleying, you have even one foot in the kitchen and/or on the kitchen line, it's a fault.
If momentum carries you or anything you are wearing or carrying into the kitchen while volleying, it's a fault.
If, right after volleying, you touch the kitchen, it's a fault. Even if the ball is declared dead before you touch the kitchen, it is still a fault.
You can stand in the kitchen at any time, so long as you're not volleying.
The kitchen is a two-dimensional rectangle, not a three-dimensional box. You can volley if the ball is over the kitchen, so long as your feet are not in the kitchen.
